docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN some friends suggested that we celebrate the Fourth of July with a picnic and a Ray Charles concert at Tanglewood, it seemed like a great idea. We arrived early, but the lawn was already crowded despite the threat of rain. We found an empty spot near the front and, feeling lucky, settled ourselves down and spread out our feast. It was not an elaborate picnic, but it drew stares from our immediate neighbors. Instead of the usual cold roast chicken, an Austrian friend, Ingeborg Hecht, made a dish I had not eaten in a long time: wiener schnitzel. She used pounded chicken breasts instead of veal (which can often be watery), and they were wonderfully juicy inside a crisp coating of bread crumbs. To go with the schnitzel we had salads of chopped tomatoes mixed with red onion and kernels of corn (easy to transport in a plastic container) and waxy Yukon gold potatoes tossed in a mustard vinaigrette with tarragon and hard-boiled eggs.

headline.main: A Feast of a Picnic With Chicken Wiener Schnitzel and Salads

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN apples replace peaches on the produce stand you know summer has segued into fall. Among the earliest fall holidays is Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year, which begins Wednesday at sunset. One of the food traditions for this celebration is eating apples with honey as a harbinger for a sweet year. Though it is easy enough simply to dip apple slices in honey, here are some other ideas for adding honey and apples to the menu.

docs.abstract: Molly O'Neill article on grilling marinated chicken breasts; recipes; photo (L)e
docs.lead_paragraph: A chicken may be the sum of its parts, but it is the parts that tell the story of time and place. In general, the South tends to be partial to legs and thighs, while the East likes the pale tender meat of the breast. Geography, however, can be superseded by the culture at large. During eras when full, rustic flavors are in vogue, the leg and wing tend to be ubiquitous. In periods of great refinement, however, breast meat is preferred, although the popularity of Buffalo-style chicken wings, which were invented as bar food in upstate New York in 1964 and went on to wow the masses in the 1970's, was a historical exception -- the 70's being a big time for breasts.

docs.abstract: Molly O'Neill article on cold soups for summer; recipes; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: The summer of cold soup was the summer our 7-year-old collie, Herschel, spent most of his days chewing up the carpet and fertilizing the furniture. He was not happy about Betty Lou's puppies, even if Betty Lou's puppies were his. (Betty Lou didn't seem too happy herself, and she and her brood permanently attached themselves to my left leg.) Our two cats were not exactly thrilled, either, and they spent their summer shredding every plant on the terrace. This, while my 5-year-old stepdaughter was obsessed with making life-size mermaids out of papier-mache (she did this at the kitchen table, every afternoon), and I was slogging through a midlife crisis. It was within this context that I turned to an odd medium for comfort. I never liked cold soup, but it was a comment on my mental state that I needed something completely out of character for solace. And it worked. The act of making and assembling it functioned as a kind of homeopathic psychogen. To the degree that cold soup is a mess, the endeavor mirrored my life. It was a joy to deliberately create a mess, contain it and order it into a delicious whole -- affixed, right before serving, with a soupcon of texture.

docs.lead_paragraph: Although a yolk is just a little more than one-third of an egg's weight, it accounts for 100 percent of its personality. Known to the tongue as rich, smooth and satiny, the yolk is the tiny sun in the center of its universe. And just as we've come to fear the sun's killer rays, we've come to fret over this most basic of foods. For one thing, the yolk contains animal fat and cholesterol, as well as most of the vitamin A, thiamine, iron and calories in an egg. It is an impeccable balance of nutrients, and in that way, almost perfect. But egg yolks are nothing if not rich, and we assume that richness and evil are inextricably intertwined, not unlike the fine net of a whipped yolk in a hot skillet.

docs.abstract: Moira Hodgson (Food) column on dishes enhanced through use of saffron; sketch (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: IT was eating paella in a Spanish restaurant recently that reminded me of how much I love the taste of saffron. This spice -- actually the dried stigma of a type of crocus, with orange and red threads that look like pipe tobacco -- is wonderful when used sparingly, adding a subtle dimension to a dish. But saffron has a penetrating aroma that can be overwhelming if too much is used, which is why some people do not take to it. But used in the right quantities, it brings out the flavor of seafood, which makes it a natural in paella and risotto (when you add it to rice, its hue begins to darken and develop like a print in a photographer's lab). It also marries well with the acid flavor of tomatoes, making it a good foil for a fatty fish like salmon. In Spain it is often combined with ground almonds, garlic and parsley and added to stews. It goes very well with the rather bland flavors of veal or chicken. Saffron is expensive -- around $5 for a small phial -- because it has to be harvested by hand. But only a few threads are needed in a dish. They should be stored away from the light or they will lose their pungency. Powdered saffron may be adulterated and is best avoided altogether.

headline.main: Adding Subtlety to Dishes With a Pinch of Saffron

docs.lead_paragraph: CHILEAN SEA BASS, A FIRM WHITE FISH WITH A large, sumptuous flake, is rapidly becoming the darling of chefs and home cooks alike. Its appeal is obvious. Mild yet full-tasting, it is easy to handle, infinitely versatile and nearly impossible to overcook. But its appearance in fish markets throughout North America has a sad subtext, I'm afraid.

docs.abstract: Molly O'Neill's Food column on cooking with pepper; recipes; photo (L)
docs.lead_paragraph: A COOK'S INABILITY TO ''SEASON TO TASTE'' can be explained in one of two ways. The cook may have spent years relying on recipes, thereby losing -- or perhaps never developing -- an instinct for using salt and pepper. Or the cook may be impervious to his own taste buds, which frankly makes it pretty difficult to season for others. Whatever the reason, this is one handicap that cannot be ignored. It is simply too crippling. Knowledge of salt and pepper, after all, is the basis of culinary literacy. Custom allows for early childhood education. The presence of salt and pepper on the table enables everyone to tailor the seasoning to his or her taste. Youthful exuberance, however, especially with pepper, can be devastating: watering eyes, a scorched tongue and a lasting phobia.

docs.lead_paragraph: BROCCOLI RAPE is an underrated vegetable. Italians and Chinese use it a great deal, but Americans have tended to overlook it because of its bitter taste, which some people find off-putting. Also known as stem broccoli, broccoli rabe or rapini, it looks like a flowering head of broccoli, but it is more closely related to the turnip family.

docs.lead_paragraph: THIS summer's crop of fresh sweet corn will soon be a memory. With the advent of fall, it is time to think about corn the way earlier generations did, as a storage grain for milling into meal or flour, extending its shelf life so it can be used in winter. Corn lacks wheat's gluten. It cannot be kneaded like wheat to make an elastic yeast-risen dough. That explains the tortilla, a traditional bread made only of corn.

headline.main: Giving Biscuits and Quick Breads the Texture and Flavor of Corn
